intro: Simbuleta bellidifolia var. lusitanica, commonly known as the Lusitanian bellflower, is a perennial herb native to southern Europe. It belongs to the Boraginaceae family, characterized by its hairy stems and showy blue or violet flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or calcareous soils, preferring sunny to partially shaded environments. Its flowers bloom in late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. The leaves are lance-shaped and have a distinctive bluish-green hue, contributing to its ornamental value in gardens.
